question_text: What is the difference between Actor, Pawn, and Character classes in Unreal?
option_d: Actor is base class for any object placed in level. Pawn extends Actor and can be possessed by controllers. Character extends Pawn with built-in movement (CharacterMovementComponent) and capsule collision. Use Actor for static objects, Pawn for controllable entities, Character for humanoids.

question_text: Why should you use Blueprints vs C++ in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Blueprints: Visual scripting, faster prototyping, designer-friendly, good for gameplay logic. C++: Better performance, complex algorithms, engine modifications, reusable code. Best practice: Use Blueprints for level design/quick iteration, C++ for core systems, expose C++ to Blueprints via UPROPERTY/UFUNCTION.

question_text: How do you create and use Gameplay Ability System (GAS) in Unreal?
option_d: GAS is framework for RPG abilities. Components: AbilitySystemComponent, GameplayAbility, GameplayEffect, AttributeSet. Steps: 1. Add AbilitySystemComponent to Actor, 2. Create AttributeSet for stats, 3. Create GameplayAbilities, 4. Apply GameplayEffects. Use for skills, buffs, damage calculations.

question_text: When should you use UObjects vs Actors in Unreal?
option_d: UObject: Base class for all Unreal objects, garbage collected, not placed in level. Actor: Extends UObject, can be placed in level, has Transform. Use UObjects for data management, utility classes, non-visual systems. Use Actors for level entities, gameplay objects, anything with world presence.

question_text: What is the difference between Tick and Timer in Unreal?
option_d: Tick: Called every frame (Actor::Tick(), Component::TickComponent()). Timer: Scheduled callback after delay (FTimerManager). Use Tick for continuous updates, Timer for delayed/periodic actions. Performance: Tick runs always (costly), Timer only when needed. Use SetTimer() with delegate for timers.

question_text: Why would you use Data Assets in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Data Assets store game data (item stats, enemy attributes) as separate assets. Benefits: Easy editing in editor, no hardcoded values, reusable, version controllable. Create via UDataAsset class, use in Blueprints/C++. Better than data tables for complex structured data.

question_text: How do you implement save/load system in Unreal?
option_d: Methods: 1. SaveGame class (USaveGame), 2. JSON serialization, 3. Custom binary. Steps: Create SaveGame subclass, implement Save/Load functions, use AsyncSaveGameToSlot/AsyncLoadGameFromSlot. Consider: What data to save (transform, stats, inventory), versioning, compression.

question_text: When should you use Interfaces vs Inheritance in Unreal?
option_d: Interfaces: Define contract without implementation, multiple interfaces per class, use for cross-cutting concerns (Damageable, Interactable). Inheritance: IS-A relationship, single inheritance, use for core hierarchy (Character → PlayerCharacter). Use interfaces for behavior, inheritance for type hierarchy.

question_text: What is the difference between UPROPERTY and UFUNCTION macros?
option_d: UPROPERTY: Exposes variables to Blueprints/editor (EditAnywhere, BlueprintReadWrite). UFUNCTION: Exposes functions to Blueprints (BlueprintCallable, BlueprintImplementableEvent). UPROPERTY for data, UFUNCTION for behavior. Both enable reflection, garbage collection, replication.

question_text: How do you optimize Unreal projects for performance?
option_d: Techniques: 1. Level of Detail (LOD), 2. Occlusion Culling, 3. Texture streaming, 4. Actor pooling, 5. Reduce draw calls, 6. Use instanced static meshes, 7. Optimize Blueprints (avoid tick, use events), 8. Profile with Unreal Insights, Stat commands. Target platforms determine optimization strategy.

question_text: Why would you use Event Dispatchers in Blueprints?
option_d: Event Dispatchers are custom events that can be bound by multiple listeners. Benefits: Decoupling, reusable event systems, Blueprint communication. Use for: UI updates, gameplay events, system notifications. Create in Blueprint, bind functions, call to trigger all bound functions. Better than direct references for loose coupling.

question_text: What is the difference between GameMode, GameState, and PlayerState?
option_d: GameMode: Rules (win conditions, player setup), exists only on server. GameState: Replicated game state (score, time), all clients see. PlayerState: Player-specific state (name, score, kills). GameMode authoritative, GameState replicated, PlayerState per player. Use for multiplayer game architecture.

question_text: How do you implement AI Behavior Trees in Unreal?
option_d: Behavior Trees define AI decision making. Components: Blackboard (memory), Behavior Tree (logic), Tasks, Services, Decorators. Steps: 1. Create Blackboard with keys, 2. Create Behavior Tree with tasks, 3. Add AIController with RunBehaviorTree(). Use for NPC behavior, enemy AI.

question_text: When would you use Niagara vs Cascade particle systems?
option_d: Cascade: Legacy system, simpler, being deprecated. Niagara: New system, more powerful, data-driven, performance benefits. Use Niagara for: Complex effects, GPU particles, custom behavior, performance-critical effects. Use Cascade only for legacy projects. Niagara supports visual scripting for effects.

question_text: Why use Subsystems in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Subsystems are automatically instantiated manager classes. Types: Engine, Editor, GameInstance, World, LocalPlayer. Benefits: Lifetime management, easy access, no manual instantiation. Use for: Game systems (audio, save), utility managers. Example: UGameInstanceSubsystem for game-wide systems.

question_text: What is the difference between World Partition and Level Streaming?
option_d: World Partition: Automatic streaming based on camera position, single persistent level. Level Streaming: Manual level loading/unloading, multiple sublevels. World Partition benefits: Large open worlds, automatic management. Level Streaming: Controlled loading, smaller games. World Partition is newer, better for open worlds.

question_text: How do you create custom material functions in Unreal?
option_d: Material Functions are reusable material nodes. Create: Material Editor → Right click → Create Material Function. Use for: Complex operations (normal mapping, custom lighting), reuse across materials. Parameters exposed as inputs. Benefits: Organization, performance (cached), maintainability.

question_text: When should you use Structs vs Classes in Unreal?
option_d: Structs: Value types, stack allocated (usually), no inheritance, lightweight. Classes: Reference types, heap allocated, inheritance, heavier. Use structs for: Simple data (Vector, Transform), small POD types. Use classes for: Complex behavior, polymorphism, large data. USTRUCT for Blueprint exposure.

question_text: What is the purpose of Delegates in Unreal C++?
option_d: Delegates are type-safe function pointers/callbacks. Types: Single-cast, multi-cast, dynamic (Blueprint). Use for: Event systems, callbacks, decoupling. Benefits: Type safety, Blueprint integration. Example: DECLARE_DYNAMIC_MULTICAST_DELEGATE for Blueprint events. Bind functions, broadcast to trigger.

question_text: How do you implement multiplayer replication in Unreal?
option_d: Replication synchronizes state between server and clients. Steps: 1. Use replication flag (bReplicates=true), 2. Mark variables with UPROPERTY(Replicated), 3. Implement GetLifetimeReplicatedProps, 4. Use RPCs (Server, Client, NetMulticast). Considerations: Bandwidth, relevancy, prediction. Use for multiplayer games.

question_text: Why would you use Animation Blueprints vs regular Animations?
option_d: Animation Blueprints: Visual scripting for animation logic, blend spaces, state machines. Regular Animations: Single animation sequences. Use Animation Blueprints for: Complex animation logic, blending, runtime control, dynamic animations. Benefits: Flexibility, visual editing, integration with gameplay.

question_text: What is the difference between BeginPlay and PostInitializeComponents?
option_d: PostInitializeComponents: Called after all components initialized, before BeginPlay. BeginPlay: Called when actor is ready to play, after level loaded. Order: Constructor → PostInitializeComponents → BeginPlay. Use PostInitializeComponents for component-dependent initialization, BeginPlay for gameplay start logic.

question_text: How do you create custom collision channels in Unreal?
option_d: Steps: 1. Project Settings → Collision → New Object Channel, 2. Define collision presets, 3. Assign to components. Use for: Custom collision interactions (projectiles, triggers). Benefits: Organized collision, performance optimization. Access in code via ECollisionChannel enum.

question_text: When should you use Data Tables in Unreal?
option_d: Data Tables store structured data in CSV/JSON. Use for: Item databases, enemy stats, localization, balancing. Benefits: Easy editing, spreadsheet import, version control. Create USTRUCT, make DataTable asset. Access via FindRow, GetAllRows. Good for large datasets, designer-friendly.

question_text: What is the purpose of Primary Assets in Unreal?
option_d: Primary Assets are game assets managed by Asset Manager for streaming/loading. Types: Maps, DataAssets, Blueprints. Benefits: Async loading, dependency tracking, chunking for DLC. Use for: Large games, streaming content, memory management. Register in PrimaryAssetTypes.

question_text: How do you implement custom UI widgets in Unreal?
option_d: Steps: 1. Create Widget Blueprint, 2. Design in UMG editor, 3. Add to viewport (CreateWidget, AddToViewport), 4. Handle input/events. Features: Binding, animations, navigation. Use for: HUD, menus, interactive UI. Consider performance: Virtualization for lists, pooling for dynamic widgets.

question_text: Why use Async Loading in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Async Loading loads assets without blocking game thread. Benefits: Smooth gameplay, no hitches, better user experience. Methods: AsyncLoadAsset, StreamableManager. Use for: Large assets, level streaming, dynamic content. Implement loading screens, progress bars. Essential for open world games.

question_text: What is the difference between SpawnActor and CreateDefaultSubobject?
option_d: SpawnActor: Creates actor instance in world at runtime. CreateDefaultSubobject: Creates component in actor constructor (editor/runtime). Use SpawnActor for dynamic actor creation. Use CreateDefaultSubobject for permanent actor components. SpawnActor returns pointer, CreateDefaultSubobject used in constructor only.

question_text: How do you profile and debug Unreal projects?
option_d: Tools: 1. Unreal Insights (frame analysis), 2. ProfileGPU/ProfileCPU commands, 3. Stat commands (Stat FPS, Stat SceneRendering), 4. Visual Logger, 5. Blueprint Debugger, 6. Memory Profiler. Use for: Performance bottlenecks, memory leaks, optimization. Essential for production debugging.

question_text: When would you use Blueprint Nativization?
option_d: Blueprint Nativization converts Blueprints to C++ during packaging. Benefits: Performance improvement, smaller package size. Use when: Blueprint performance critical, shipping final build. Considerations: Debugging harder, longer packaging time. Configure in Project Settings → Packaging → Blueprint Nativization.

question_text: What is the purpose of Meta Sounds in Unreal Engine 5?
option_d: Meta Sounds: New audio system replacing Sound Cue. Features: Graph-based audio, real-time DSP, performance benefits. Use for: Complex audio logic, procedural audio, dynamic mixing. Benefits: Visual editing, C++ integration, better performance. Part of Audio Engine overhaul in UE5.

question_text: How do you implement custom shaders in Unreal?
option_d: Methods: 1. Custom Material Nodes (HLSL), 2. Plugin with shader files, 3. Material Expressions. Steps: Write HLSL code, integrate via Custom node or plugin. Use for: Special effects, visual style, performance optimization. Advanced: Requires shader compilation knowledge.

question_text: Why use Chaos Physics in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Chaos Physics: New physics system replacing PhysX. Benefits: Better destruction, scalability, deterministic results. Features: Destruction, cloth, vehicles, particles. Use for: Destructible environments, complex physics simulations. Configure in Project Settings → Physics → Chaos.

question_text: What is the difference between Soft References and Hard References?
option_d: Hard References: Direct pointer, loads asset with referencer. Soft References: String-based (FSoftObjectPtr), loads on demand. Use soft references for: Optional assets, reducing memory, dynamic loading. Benefits: Faster startup, smaller memory footprint. Convert via LoadObject, AsyncLoad.

question_text: How do you create procedural meshes at runtime?
option_d: Use ProceduralMeshComponent or RuntimeMeshComponent. Steps: 1. Create vertex data, 2. Define triangles, 3. Set normals/UVs, 4. Update mesh. Use for: Dynamic geometry, terrain, custom shapes. Considerations: Performance, memory. Alternative: Use static meshes when possible, procedural for dynamic.

question_text: When should you use World Composition vs World Partition?
option_d: World Composition: Legacy system for large worlds, manual level streaming. World Partition: Newer, automatic, data-driven. Use World Partition for new projects (UE5+). World Composition only for legacy projects. World Partition benefits: Automatic streaming, better editor integration.

question_text: What is the purpose of Slate UI framework in Unreal?
option_d: Slate: C++ UI framework underlying UMG. Use for: Editor extensions, complex UI, performance-critical UI. Benefits: Full C++ control, no Blueprint overhead. Drawback: More complex than UMG. Use UMG for game UI, Slate for editor tools.

question_text: How do you implement custom input mappings in Unreal?
option_d: Steps: 1. Project Settings → Input → Action/Axis Mappings, 2. Bind in Blueprint/C++ (BindAction, BindAxis), 3. Handle events. Enhanced Input System: New system with contexts, modifiers. Use for: Complex input, gamepad support, input rebinding. Benefits: Better organization, context sensitivity.

question_text: Why use Gameplay Tags in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Gameplay Tags: Hierarchical string tags for categorization. Benefits: Fast comparisons, organization, Blueprint/C++ support. Use for: Ability systems, state management, filtering. Better than enums for: Dynamic tags, multiple categories. Create in Project Settings → Gameplay Tags.

question_text: What is the difference between Instanced Static Mesh and Hierarchical Instanced Static Mesh?
option_d: Instanced Static Mesh (ISM): Batches identical meshes, single LOD. Hierarchical Instanced Static Mesh (HISM): Adds LOD support, culling, better performance for many instances. Use ISM for few instances, HISM for many (foliage, buildings). HISM supports per-instance data, LOD transitions.

question_text: How do you create custom editor tools in Unreal?
option_d: Methods: 1. Editor Utility Widgets (Blueprint), 2. Slate (C++), 3. Python scripting. Steps for C++: Create module, implement IModuleInterface, build editor-only code. Use for: Level design tools, asset processing, automation. Benefits: Workflow improvement, automation.

question_text: When should you use Blueprint Function Libraries?
option_d: Blueprint Function Libraries: Static function collections accessible in Blueprints. Use for: Utility functions, math operations, string manipulation, reusable logic. Benefits: Organization, no object instance needed. Create via Blueprint Function Library class. Use instead of duplicate Blueprint nodes.

question_text: What is the purpose of Reflection System in Unreal?
option_d: Reflection: Runtime type information system. Benefits: Blueprint exposure, serialization, garbage collection, networking. Implemented via UPROPERTY/UFUNCTION macros. Allows: Dynamic casting, property iteration, editor integration. Essential for Unreal's feature set.

question_text: How do you implement destructible environments?
option_d: Methods: 1. Chaos Destruction system, 2. Pre-fractured meshes, 3. Procedural breaking. Steps for Chaos: Create destructible mesh, apply damage via ApplyDamage. Use for: Breakable objects, environmental destruction. Considerations: Performance, debris cleanup. Configure in Chaos Destruction settings.

question_text: Why use Plugin system in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Plugins: Modular code/assets that extend engine. Benefits: Reusability across projects, separation of concerns, marketplace distribution. Types: Runtime, Editor, Both. Use for: Third-party integrations, engine modifications, feature modules. Create via Plugin Creator.

question_text: What is the difference between Sweep and Teleport in movement?
option_d: Sweep: Moves with collision checking, returns hit results, prevents passing through objects. Teleport: Instantly moves without collision checking. Use Sweep for: Character movement, physics objects. Use Teleport for: Respawn, cutscenes, non-physical movement. SetSweep parameter in MoveComponent functions.

question_text: How do you create custom collision shapes?
option_d: Methods: 1. Complex as Simple (use mesh collision), 2. Custom collision via collision primitives (spheres, boxes, capsules), 3. PhysX convex decomposition. Use for: Accurate collision, performance optimization. Configure in Static Mesh editor → Collision. Consider: Performance vs accuracy trade-off.

question_text: When should you use Blueprint Macro Libraries?
option_d: Blueprint Macro Libraries: Reusable graph snippets with inputs/outputs. Use for: Complex node sequences, reducing graph clutter, standardized patterns. Benefits: Code reuse, parameterization. Differences from functions: Macros are inlined (copied), functions are called. Use macros for visual clarity, functions for logic reuse.

question_text: What is the purpose of Precomputed Visibility in Unreal?
option_d: Precomputed Visibility: Baked visibility data for static levels. Benefits: Runtime performance, occlusion culling optimization. Use for: Indoor scenes, complex static geometry. Limitations: Dynamic objects not handled, increased build time. Configure in World Settings → Precomputed Visibility.

question_text: How do you implement weather systems in Unreal?
option_d: Components: 1. Particle systems (rain, snow), 2. Material effects (wet surfaces), 3. Lighting changes, 4. Audio, 5. Post-processing. Use: Niagara for particles, Material Parameter Collections for global changes, Time of Day system. Implement transitions, weather states. Consider performance optimization.

question_text: Why use Distance Field Ambient Occlusion (DFAO)?
option_d: DFAO: Screen-space ambient occlusion using distance fields. Benefits: Accurate soft shadows, performance efficient, works with dynamic objects. Use for: Realistic ambient occlusion, indirect lighting. Configure in Project Settings → Rendering → Ambient Occlusion. Better than SSAO for accuracy, but higher memory.

question_text: What is the difference between AddDynamic and BindUObject?
option_d: AddDynamic: Binds Blueprint function to dynamic delegate. BindUObject: Binds C++ UObject member function to delegate. Use AddDynamic for Blueprint integration, BindUObject for C++. Both create callback connections. Remember to unbind when object destroyed to prevent crashes.

question_text: How do you create custom asset import pipelines?
option_d: Methods: 1. Python scripting (Editor Scripting Utilities), 2. Custom asset factories, 3. Import plugins. Use for: Automated asset processing, format conversion, batch operations. Benefits: Workflow automation, consistency. Implement via UFactory subclass or Python scripts.

question_text: When should you use Runtime Virtual Texturing (RVT)?
option_d: RVT: Streaming texture system for large terrains. Use for: Terrain blending, decal projection, large texture resolution. Benefits: Memory efficiency, seamless blending. Configure: Enable in Project Settings, create RVT volumes. Use cases: Open world games, terrain materials.

question_text: What is the purpose of Level Instance actors?
option_d: Level Instance: Reusable level片段 as single actor. Benefits: Modular level design, performance (batch loading), consistency. Use for: Building pieces, room templates, reusable layouts. Edit in separate level, instance in main level. Better than Blueprints for complex geometry.

question_text: How do you implement custom locomotion for characters?
option_d: Steps: 1. Modify CharacterMovementComponent, 2. Custom Animation Blueprint, 3. Root motion, 4. Custom movement modes. Use for: Parkour, climbing, specialized movement. Considerations: Network replication, physics interaction. Extend UCharacterMovementComponent for custom logic.

question_text: Why use Control Rig for animation in Unreal?
option_d: Control Rig: Procedural animation system. Benefits: Runtime animation, physics-based, programmatic control. Use for: Dynamic animations, IK solving, procedural motion. Better than: Traditional animation for dynamic scenarios. Integrates with Animation Blueprints. Use for characters, objects, effects.

question_text: What is the difference between Material Instances and Material Parameters?
option_d: Material Instances: Instances of parent material with overridden parameters. Material Parameters: Exposed variables in materials (scalar, vector, texture). Use instances for material variations, parameters for runtime changes. Dynamic Material Instances allow runtime parameter modification via SetVectorParameterValue etc.

question_text: How do you create custom HLSL nodes in materials?
option_d: Custom HLSL nodes: Write HLSL code in Material Editor. Use for: Complex calculations not available in standard nodes. Steps: Add Custom node, write HLSL, define inputs/outputs. Benefits: Performance optimization, special effects. Considerations: Shader compilation complexity, platform support.

question_text: When should you use Scene Capture components?
option_d: Scene Capture: Renders scene to texture from camera view. Use for: Security cameras, mirrors, portals, minimaps, reflections. Types: SceneCapture2D, SceneCaptureCube. Configure: What to render (primitives), post-processing. Performance cost: Additional render pass. Use judiciously.

question_text: What is the purpose of Mass AI framework in Unreal?
option_d: Mass AI: Entity Component System for large-scale AI. Benefits: Performance for thousands of entities, data-oriented design. Use for: Crowd simulations, RTS units, large NPC groups. Components: MassEntity, Processors, Traits. Alternative to Behavior Trees for simple, numerous AI.

question_text: How do you implement custom post-processing effects?
option_d: Methods: 1. Post Process Materials, 2. Custom Render Passes, 3. Plugin with shaders. Steps: Create material with PostProcess domain, add to Post Process Volume. Use for: Screen effects, color grading, distortions. Advanced: Implement custom Scene View Extension for full control.

question_text: Why use Async Trace for collision queries?
option_d: Async Trace: Non-blocking collision queries on separate thread. Benefits: No game thread stalls, better performance for many queries. Use for: AI perception, bullet traces, frequent checks. Implement via AsyncTrace methods. Considerations: Results delayed by one frame, callback handling.

question_text: What is the difference between World Settings and Project Settings?
option_d: World Settings: Per-level settings (game mode, navigation, physics). Project Settings: Global project settings (input, rendering, platforms). World Settings affect current level, Project Settings affect entire project. Both accessible via editor menus. Important for multiplayer (replicated settings).

question_text: How do you create custom navigation areas?
option_d: Custom Navigation Areas: Define costs for different surfaces. Steps: 1. Project Settings → Navigation System → Supported Areas, 2. Assign to nav mesh, 3. Use in pathfinding. Use for: Different movement costs (water, mud, roads). AI considers area costs when pathfinding. Implement via UNavArea class.

question_text: When should you use Curve Assets in Unreal?
option_d: Curve Assets: Float curves for animation/interpolation. Use for: Non-linear timing, easing functions, parameter animation. Benefits: Editor editing, runtime evaluation. Use cases: Camera movement, UI animations, procedural animation. Create in Curve Editor, evaluate via GetFloatValue. Better than linear interpolation for polished motion.

question_text: What is the purpose of Landmass plugin for terrain?
option_d: Landmass plugin: Procedural terrain generation tool. Benefits: Dynamic terrain creation, erosion simulation, realistic landscapes. Use for: Open world terrain, level prototyping. Features: Sculpting, erosion, material painting. Integrates with Landscape system. Alternative to manual terrain sculpting.

question_text: How do you implement custom rendering passes?
option_d: Custom rendering passes: Additional render stages. Methods: 1. Render Target rendering, 2. Custom depth/stencil, 3. Plugin with RHI commands. Use for: Special effects, GPU computations, custom lighting. Advanced: Requires knowledge of Unreal's rendering pipeline. Use Scene View Extensions for integration.

question_text: Why use Nanite virtualized geometry in Unreal Engine 5?
option_d: Nanite: Virtualized geometry system for extremely high poly counts. Benefits: No LODs needed, automatic streaming, cinematic quality assets. Use for: Film-quality assets, complex environments, eliminating LOD work. Limitations: Doesn't support deformable meshes (skinned). Enable in project settings, works with static meshes.

question_text: What is the difference between Blueprint Native Events and regular functions?
option_d: Blueprint Native Events: C++ functions Blueprints can override (BlueprintImplementableEvent). Regular functions: Standard C++ functions. Native events allow Blueprint customization without modifying C++. Use for: Designer customization points, modding support. Implement in C++ with empty body, override in Blueprints.

question_text: How do you create custom detail panels in editor?
option_d: Custom Detail Panels: Extend property editor for components/actors. Methods: 1. Detail customization via IDetailCustomization, 2. Property type customization. Use for: Enhanced editing, custom controls, workflow tools. Implement in editor module. Benefits: Better UX for complex assets.

question_text: When should you use Automation Testing in Unreal?
option_d: Automation Testing: Automated tests for functionality/regression. Use for: Core systems testing, performance benchmarks, smoke tests. Benefits: Catch regressions, ensure stability, CI/CD integration. Types: Functional, performance, screenshot comparison. Implement via Automation Spec, run in editor or command line.

question_text: What is the purpose of Pixel Streaming in Unreal?
option_d: Pixel Streaming: Stream rendered frames to web browsers. Benefits: No local installation, cross-platform, scalable. Use for: Cloud gaming, demos, remote collaboration. Architecture: Unreal app renders, encodes, streams via WebRTC. Client: HTML5 page receives video. Configure in Project Settings.

question_text: How do you implement custom vehicle physics?
option_d: Methods: 1. Chaos Vehicle system, 2. Custom movement component, 3. Physics constraints. Steps for Chaos: Create vehicle Blueprint, configure wheels, engine, suspension. Use for: Racing games, realistic vehicle simulation. Configure in Physics Asset, tune parameters (torque, friction).

question_text: Why use Temporal Super Resolution (TSR) in Unreal Engine 5?
option_d: TSR: Temporal upscaling technique. Benefits: Better image quality than TAAU, performance improvement, reduced aliasing. Use for: High-quality rendering at lower resolution. Configure in Anti-Aliasing settings. Comparison: TSR better for motion, clarity. Essential for performance/quality balance in UE5.

question_text: What is the difference between Build and Cook in Unreal?
option_d: Build: Compiles code, generates binaries. Cook: Prepares assets for target platform (texture compression, format conversion). Build happens first, then Cook. Cook essential for packaging. Settings in Project Settings → Packaging. Cook also strips unused assets, optimizes.

question_text: How do you create custom asset registry tags?
option_d: Custom asset registry tags: Metadata for asset organization/search. Steps: 1. Implement GetAssetRegistryTags in UObject, 2. Add tags via FAssetRegistryModule. Use for: Custom categorization, search filters, asset management. Benefits: Better asset organization, tool integration.

question_text: When should you use World Alignment in materials?
option_d: World Alignment: Align material patterns to world coordinates. Use for: Tiling textures on large surfaces, consistent patterns across objects. Benefits: No texture stretching, seamless tiling. Configure via Texture Coordinate node with World Alignment. Use cases: Terrain, buildings, large environments.

question_text: What is the purpose of One File Per Actor (OFPA) system?
option_d: OFPA: Stores each actor in separate file within World Partition. Benefits: Version control friendly, parallel editing, faster loading. Use for: Large teams, collaborative level design. Enables: Checkout individual actors, no level file conflicts. Configure in World Partition settings. Essential for team projects.

question_text: How do you implement custom skeletal mesh deformation?
option_d: Custom skeletal mesh deformation: Modify vertex positions at runtime. Methods: 1. Morph targets, 2. Anim Dynamics (physics), 3. Custom anim node, 4. Control Rig. Use for: Clothing simulation, muscle flexing, procedural deformation. Implement via Anim Graph nodes or C++ animation system.

question_text: Why use Volumetric Fog in Unreal Engine?
option_d: Volumetric Fog: 3D fog with light scattering. Benefits: Realistic atmosphere, god rays, depth. Use for: Atmospheric effects, mood setting, realistic lighting. Configure in Exponential Height Fog with Volumetric Fog enabled. Performance cost: Significant, use judiciously. Essential for realistic outdoor scenes.

question_text: What is the difference between Additive and Multiply blend modes?
option_d: Additive: Adds material color to background (brightening). Multiply: Multiplies material color with background (darkening). Use Additive for: Glows, lights, fire. Use Multiply for: Shadows, tints, overlays. Other modes: Translucent (alpha blending), Masked (binary transparency). Choose based on desired visual effect.

question_text: How do you create custom asset actions in content browser?
option_d: Custom asset actions: Context menu items for assets. Methods: 1. AssetTypeActions class, 2. Content Browser extensions. Use for: Batch processing, custom workflows, asset management. Implement in editor module. Benefits: Workflow automation, tool integration.

question_text: When should you use Material Layers in Unreal?
option_d: Material Layers: Stack material functions for complex surfaces. Use for: Terrain materials, layered surfaces (dirt+grass+snow). Benefits: Reusability, organization, performance. Create Material Layer functions, blend via Material Attribute layers. Better than complex material graphs for organized workflows.

question_text: What is the purpose of Foliage System in Unreal?
option_d: Foliage System: Paint vegetation/objects on landscapes. Benefits: Performance optimization (instancing), realistic environments, easy editing. Use for: Grass, trees, rocks, scattered objects. Features: Painting, scaling, randomization, collision. Configure via Foliage Mode in editor. Essential for natural environments.

question_text: How do you implement custom sound attenuation?
option_d: Custom sound attenuation: Control how sound volume decreases with distance. Methods: 1. Sound Attenuation assets, 2. Custom attenuation via Blueprints/C++. Configure: Distance algorithm, falloff curve, spatialization. Use for: Realistic audio, gameplay cues, performance optimization. Create in Sound Attenuation editor.

question_text: Why use Reflection Capture actors in Unreal?
option_d: Reflection Capture: Capture environment for reflections. Types: Sphere, Box, Plane. Benefits: Performance (cubemap vs screen-space), accuracy for static scenes. Use for: Shiny surfaces, water, metallic materials. Place in scene, capture surroundings. Update dynamically if needed.

question_text: What is the difference between Static and Stationary lights?
option_d: Static lights: Baked into lightmaps, no runtime cost. Stationary lights: Mixed baked/dynamic, can change color/intensity at runtime. Use Static for: Fully static scenes, performance. Use Stationary for: Partially dynamic scenes, some runtime changes. Movable lights: Fully dynamic, highest cost.

question_text: How do you create custom console commands?
option_d: Custom console commands: Developer commands for debugging/testing. Methods: 1. Exec functions in actors, 2. IConsoleManager::RegisterConsoleCommand. Use for: Cheats, debugging, performance testing. Benefits: Quick testing, automation. Implement in C++, call via tilde (~) console.

question_text: When should you use Mesh Distance Fields?
option_d: Mesh Distance Fields: Precomputed distance to mesh surface. Use for: Soft shadows, ambient occlusion, global illumination. Benefits: Better quality than traditional methods, works with dynamic objects. Performance cost: Memory, baking time. Enable in Project Settings → Generate Mesh Distance Fields.

question_text: What is the purpose of Asset Audit in Unreal?
option_d: Asset Audit: Analyze asset usage, dependencies, size. Use for: Optimization, memory management, project cleanup. Tools: Size Map, Reference Viewer, Asset Manager. Benefits: Identify unused assets, optimize package size, manage dependencies. Essential for shipping optimization.

question_text: How do you implement custom collision responses?
option_d: Custom collision responses: Define what happens when objects collide. Methods: 1. Collision Presets, 2. SetCollisionResponseToChannel, 3. OnHit/Overlap events. Use for: Gameplay interactions, physics behavior. Configure in Project Settings → Collision. Implement response logic in event handlers.

question_text: Why use Hierarchical LOD (HLOD) system in Unreal?
option_d: HLOD: Groups distant actors into simplified meshes. Benefits: Performance for large scenes, draw call reduction. Use for: Open worlds, complex scenes. Configure in HLOD settings, generate via HLOD tool. Combines meshes, materials for distance rendering. Essential for performance in large levels.

question_text: What is the difference between Simulate and Play in editor?
option_d: Simulate: Runs game in editor with editor camera control, debug features. Play: Starts actual game with proper player controller. Use Simulate for: Quick testing, debugging, level design. Use Play for: Final testing, gameplay flow. Simulate preserves editor state, Play loads game fully.

question_text: How do you create custom animation montages?
option_d: Animation Montages: Sequence of animations with notifies. Create: Animation editor → Create Montage. Features: Sections, slots, blend spaces. Use for: Attack combos, interactions, cinematic sequences. Implement via PlayMontage in code. Configure blending, root motion. Essential for gameplay animations.

question_text: When should you use Material Parameter Collections?
option_d: Material Parameter Collections: Global material parameters shared across materials. Use for: Weather effects, time of day, global color changes. Benefits: Single control point, performance efficient. Update via SetVectorParameterValue in code. Better than individual material parameters for global effects.

question_text: What is the purpose of Visual Logger in Unreal?
option_d: Visual Logger: Records and visualizes debug data in world. Use for: AI debugging, gameplay analysis, performance visualization. Benefits: See data spatially, time-based analysis. Record via UE_LOG with VisualLog category. Playback in editor to analyze behavior. Essential for complex system debugging.

question_text: How do you implement custom navigation mesh generation?
option_d: Custom nav mesh generation: Modify navigation data at runtime. Methods: 1. Navigation modifiers, 2. Dynamic navigation updates, 3. Custom nav data. Use for: Destructible environments, dynamic obstacles. Implement via NavigationSystem, Rebuild navigation when needed. Performance considerations for dynamic updates.

question_text: Why use Procedural Content Generation (PCG) framework?
option_d: PCG framework: Node-based procedural content generation. Benefits: Automated level creation, variation, iteration speed. Use for: Environment generation, asset placement, world building. Features: Graph-based, runtime/editor generation. Alternative to manual placement for large-scale content.

question_text: What is the difference between World Space and Local Space in animations?
option_d: World Space: Global coordinates (scene origin). Local Space: Relative to parent bone/component. Use World Space for: Global positioning, root motion. Use Local Space for: Relative bone movements, blending. Animation curves can be in either space. Important for animation retargeting, blending.

question_text: How do you create custom Blueprint nodes?
option_d: Custom Blueprint nodes: Extend Blueprint visual scripting. Methods: 1. Blueprint Function Libraries, 2. Custom K2Node (C++), 3. Macro libraries. Use for: Complex operations, engine extensions, performance optimization. Implement in C++ with UK2Node base class. Expose to Blueprints with appropriate metadata.
